attributes.title: Physical Stock Take
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • A physical stock-take of raw materials and finished product was conducted on 8th April 2025 to review the adequacy and effectiveness of existing stock controls at Nakuru branch.
  • We noted that there were stock items with variations listed and tabulated below:
    • Polybags had a variance of +688 Pieces.
    • Finished product had a variance of -91 pieces
    • White flour had a variance of +10.07 Kgs equivalent to 38 Loaves.
    • Wheat Bran had a variation of +8.357
    • Yeast had a variation of -3.828 pieces while all other materials had negligible variations as shown below:
attributes.recommendation: • The branch management should institute strong stock management policies to counter the possibility of variations in stock items.
attributes.effect: • Variances in stock items especially when there were weekly stock adjustments imply weak stock controls.

value: • We have existing stock controls, but we will enforce them further and follow up to ensure there are no major variations.
• We will strengthen internal stock controls and closely monitor the movement of materials to the production floor to minimize the variances noted.

In the prior audit report dated 27th February 2025 stocks were as seen below:

  • Bread -47.25 pcs
  • Polybags +101 pcs.
  • The rest of the stock items had minimal variances.
• Variances in stock items especially when there were weekly stock adjustments imply weak stock controls.

attributes.title: Bread  Weight
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • A spot check on the weights of bread produced at Kitengela branch was done on 17th March 2025 to ascertain if the branch was compliant with the Weights and Measures Act (Sale of Bread Rules) Legal Notice 94 of 1970.
  • We noted minor instances of non-compliance to the standard weights as detailed below:
attributes.recommendation: • The branch to ensure adherence to the required dough/bread weight standards and weighing procedures.
attributes.effect:
Implication:

  • The presence of major underweight bread in 600g Barrel White implied lapses in adhering to the standard dough weights and failure to weigh bread before packing.

value: • We will increase supervision and ensure the weights are checked.
• There is need to adhere to operational procedures in production ranging from dough dividers to the oven men to packers working together to avoid instances of underweight loaves.
•  In the previous audit report, packed bread underweights were noted as follows; 400g - 37%, 400 Barrel- 57%, 600g -30.7% and 800gW-57%.

attributes.title: Bread Damages Analysis
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • We conducted a review of damages arising from production and market delivery/transit processes for the period 1st March to 7th April 2025 to detect if the damage levels were within the set limits.
  • The findings were as follows:
     
    • Production damage was 0.285% of the total production which was above the set standard of 0.2% with a cost implication of KES 30,712.37
    • The market damage was 0.78% of the total sales, which was above the 0.5% allowed limit and had a cost implication of KES 105,216.64 as computed below.
  • We also noted that there was a cumulative of 1,137.50 damaged loaves (982.75 for supermarkets and 154.75 for market damages) posted in the system but not recorded in the branch books. Therefore, the computation below was inclusive of the unrecorded damages noted.
attributes.recommendation: •  Enhance quality controls within the production and bread delivery processes to ensure there are minimal/acceptable levels of both production and market damages.
attributes.effect:
Implication:

  • The production and market damage levels were above the set limits which implied unbudgeted losses/cost incurred due to excess damages.

value:
• We will liaise with the sales team to do proper production planning to prevent instances of excess returns.
  • We will try to improve the quality of bread produced.
•  We will liaise with the sales team to do proper production planning  and the manager has been advised to ensure returns are well controlled to minimize the damage levels.
• During the prior audit dated 27th  February 2025, it was noted that production damages were 0.30% of the production and market damages stood at 0.51% of the total sales.

attributes.title: Mixing Chart Analysis
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • We conducted an analysis of both the mixing charts and mixing chart summaries for the period 1st March to 7th April 2025 to determine if the raw materials’ consumption were as per the set BOM and if the set yield and quality standards were achieved for production.
  • The following were noted:
    • Average yield was 191.50 loaves per bag
    • Average production was was 93.68 bags equivalent to 83.65% of the set target of 112 bags.
    • Utto units consumption to bags of flour ratio was 1:1
    • No cases of remixes were observed for the reviewed audit period as detailed in the table below:
attributes.recommendation: • The branch management should work towards attaining full branch capacity production.
attributes.effect: • The branch had underutilized its production capacity by 16.35%.

value: • The production target could not be reached due to balance control from our end since we are dependent on sales levels for production planning.
• The production target could not be reached due to balance control from our end since we are dependent on sales levels for production planning.

During the prior audit, the following were noted:

  • Average yield 191.52

  •  Average production 81.57 bags.

  • 396 remixes were observed.
There is room for improvement on the production target.

attributes.title: Cash Verification
attributes.description:
Findings.

  •  A cash count done on 9th April 2025 revealed that there was a variance amounting to KES 331,920 still pending in the cashflow records attributed to lost cash by a previous cashier with a pending case.
  • We also observed that there were 2 pending IOUs dated 3rd & 8th April worth KES 14,000.
attributes.recommendation: • Follow up on cashflow treatment of the lost cash. There was need to remove it from the cashflow to avoid overstating the branch’s cash balances at hand/assets.
attributes.effect:
• Cash controls were questionable due to exploited loopholes that led to loss of cash as noted above.
  • Pending IOU dated 3rd April implied non-compliance to the 3-day IOU clearance policy.

value: • The issue is with Finance and Legal team, we are waiting for their direction on way the way forward.
• The previous audit report dated 27th February 2025 indicated a variance of KES 331,913 and 3 pending IOUs.

attributes.title: Debtors' Analysis
attributes.description:
Findings.

  •  An analysis of the debt balances as at C.O.B 08/04/2025 (Exclusive of Institutions) was performed to identify any occurrences of bad debts or unresolved balances by route.
  • We noted that the outstanding debt for customers and schools was KES 361,460.90 as detailed in Appendix II below.
attributes.recommendation: •  Follow up on pending balances for clearance.
attributes.effect: • Debt balances were an indication of long outstanding debts that could potentially become bad debts.
attributes.remediation_plan: • Follow up to be done on pending balances for clearance.

value:
• The sales representative is following up.
  • Sales Rep Comment-Ongeri
    •  Some customers clear before next order, schools clear monthly and there is one dormant account which I am following up to get letter from customer to allow us to recover from security deposit.
• The previous audit noted that there was an outstanding balance of KES 254,371.70 and two dormant accounts totaling to KES 16,395.80
• Debt balances were an indication of long outstanding debts that could potentially become bad debts.

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • A review was done on the efficiency of criteria for labour allocation to the production section for the period 1st March to 7th April 2025.
  • We noted that the average production efficiency was 4.34 bags per production worker which was within the set standard of 4.5.
  • The results were as detailed below:
attributes.recommendation: • Branch management to maintain optimal allocation of employees to the production section.
attributes.effect:
Implication:

  • The branch attained the set target implying optimal allocation of workers to the production section.

value: • The previous audit report dated 27th February 2025 indicated a production efficiency of 4.21 bags per production worker.

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • An assessment was conducted on the utilization of packers in the slicing section to determine if optimality was attained based on the set Company standard of 97 crates per packer.
  • We noted that, for the period 1st March to 7th April 2025, the packing efficiency stood at 92.71 crates per packer, which was subpar compared to the set standard as demonstrated below:
attributes.recommendation: • The branch management should work towards optimizing the allocation of packers based on the set standards.
attributes.effect: • The branch did not attain the set packing efficiency implying an excess allocation of 21 packers with a cost implication of KES 19,152.

value: • We will try to push for adequate planning of  employees’ allocation to ensure optimal levels of efficiency going forward.
• We will try to push for adequate planning of  employees’ allocation to ensure optimal levels of efficiency going forward.
• The previous audit report dated 27th  February 2025  indicated a packing efficiency of of 84.92 crates per packer.

attributes.title: Vehicle Fuel Consumption Analysis
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • A review was conducted on the branch vehicles’ fuel consumption vis a vis the set standard consumption rate to determine if there was optimal utilization of fuel for the period 1st March to 9th April 2025.
  • All route vehicles’ fuel consumptions were within the set standard as detailed in Appendix I(a) & I(b) below except for a few instances which had explanations/reasons as shown in the remarks.
     

Appendix 1(a)
attributes.recommendation: •  Maintain the fuel management controls within the branch
attributes.effect: • Fuel consumption for vehicles at the branch was well controlled.
attributes.remediation_plan: • Institute adequate fuel management controls within the branch.

value: • During the previous audit dated 27th February 2025, all vehicles consumed fuel within the standards rates.
• Fuel consumption for vehicles at the branch was well controlled.
